content:
It sounds like your incoming mail (IMAP/POP) settings are fine since the inbox is syncing, but the problem is likely with your outgoing mail (SMTP) configuration. Most email apps require you to set the SMTP server, port, and authentication separately from the inbox settings.

Here are a few things to check:

SMTP Server Details – Make sure the server address, port (often 465 or 587), and encryption type (SSL/TLS) match your email provider’s requirements.

Authentication – Many providers require “Use same username and password as incoming mail” to be enabled for sending.

Firewall/Antivirus – Occasionally, security software can block outgoing connections. Temporarily disabling it (for testing) can help identify if that’s the cause.

Provider Restrictions – Some providers block SMTP on mobile or public networks unless you use their official app or enable special settings like “Allow less secure apps.”

Once your SMTP settings are correct, sending should work right away. I had a similar issue after migrating my emails — fixed it by adjusting the port and enabling authentication. And while I was troubleshooting, I had a Kuromi wallpaper on my desktop, which at least kept the process a bit more cheerful!
